docs.snippet: The Connecticut combines with her capacity as a transport ship strength and staunchness enough to make her quite formidable as a vessel of war. She is pierced for six guns, and is, therefore, fully able to relieve the monotony of her peaceful...

headline.main: AFFAIRS AT FORT PICKENS.; Interesting Statement of an Officer of the Connecticut. The Late Bombardment Tremendous Damage Inflicted upon the Rebels The Niagara and Richmond, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Connecticut combines with her capacity as a transport ship strength and staunchness enough to make her quite formidable as a vessel of war. She is pierced for six guns, and is, therefore, fully able to relieve the monotony of her peaceful carrying avocation with occasional dashes after prizes, or a brush now and then with a rebel privateer.

docs.snippet: Returning here after a three weeks' absence, I am surprised at the wonderful change which has been effected in the appearance of the place. Evidences of indomitable Yankee energy are abundant. A single rickety plantation residence, with its halfdozen...

headline.main: LATER FROM PORT ROYAL.; The wonderful Changes Effected at Hilton Head Evidences of Yankee Industry Conversations with the Negroes What They Say of their Late Masters Visits to the Surrounding Plantations, & c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Returning here after a three weeks' absence, I am surprised at the wonderful change which has been effected in the appearance of the place. Evidences of indomitable Yankee energy are abundant. A single rickety plantation residence, with its halfdozen straggling outhouses, and a frame hut near the fort, erected by the rebels as a make-shift barrack, were the only buildings on Hilton Head when our army took possession.

docs.snippet: The U.S. steamship Connecticut, Commander MAXWELL WOODHULL, from Galveston, Nov. 29; Southwest Pass, Dec. 1; Ship Island, Dec. 2; Mobile Bar and Fort Pickens, Dec. 3; Key West, Dec. 10; Savannah, Dec. 12, and Fortress Monroe, Dec. 16, arrived at this...

headline.main: ARRIVAL OF THE CONNECTICUT.; News from the Gulf, Tybee Island, and Port Royal. Forty-eight Prisoners of War Brought to This Port. TYBEE ISLAND PERMANENTLY OCCUPIED. An Expedition to Fernandina, Florida.The Capture of the Rebel Schooner Royal Yacht in Galveston Bay. CONDITION OF AFFAIRS AT FORT PICKENS.The Terrible Punishment Suffered by the Rebels.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. steamship Connecticut, Commander MAXWELL WOODHULL, from Galveston, Nov. 29; Southwest Pass, Dec. 1; Ship Island, Dec. 2; Mobile Bar and Fort Pickens, Dec. 3; Key West, Dec. 10; Savannah, Dec. 12, and Fortress Monroe, Dec. 16, arrived at this port yesterday. The crews of the blockading squadrons and the troops are all in good health. Left at Key West the U.S. steamer Richmond, coaling and repairing.

docs.snippet: The reports that have thus far reached us concerning the escape of the privateer Sumter from the United States steamer Iroquois, involved the very severest censure of Capt. PALMER, whose failure to seize her certainly stands in need of explanation....

headline.main: THE AFFAIR OF THE SUMTER.; How She Came to Escape from the Iroquois. Letters from Capt. Palmer and Other Officers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The reports that have thus far reached us concerning the escape of the privateer Sumter from the United States steamer Iroquois, involved the very severest censure of Capt. PALMER, whose failure to seize her certainly stands in need of explanation. Simple justice, however, demands that he should no be condemned unheard.

docs.snippet: --To remind us of certain dues which fall about Christmas time, JAMES MILLER publishes in royal quarto form a sumptuous volume--Lyra Germanica--a selection of hymns from Chevalier BUNSEN'S comprehensive collection, Versuch eines Allgemeinen Gesang...
docs.lead_paragraph: --To remind us of certain dues which fall about Christmas time, JAMES MILLER publishes in royal quarto form a sumptuous volume--Lyra Germanica--a selection of hymns from Chevalier BUNSEN'S comprehensive collection, Versuch eines Allgemeinen Gesang and Gebetbuchs, translated from the original by CATHARINE WINKWORTH. The German language, in its wealth of sacred poetry, is rivaled by no other.
